Regarding environmental factors for MSA, since an occupational history of farming has been reported to increase the risk of MSA in European populations,
21) whether occupational exposure to pesticides was associated with European MSA has attracted considerable attention. However, subsequent studies found no associations between occupational exposure to pesticides and European patients with MSA.
22, 23) In Asian countries, occupational histories of farming or exposure to pesticides likewise have not been found to be associated with risk of MSA in a Korean cohort, in which MSA-C patients accounted for 73%.
10) Further epidemiological studies are needed to provide clues on possible environmental factors that contribute to the differences demonstrated in clinical and pathological subtypes of MSA in different populations.
